Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling returns home from school visibly upset after a difficult day with friends.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Requesting a signature upon delivery for moderately valuable items
Story:
I had just finished my delivery route for the day, the last package—a moderately valuable one—still in my hands as I walked up the steps to my own front door. My stepbrother, Max, was slumped on the porch, his backpack at his feet, eyes red and puffy. I could tell something was wrong; he barely looked up when I greeted him. As his step-sibling, I knew I should sit down, ask him what happened, and be there for him. That’s what we promised each other after our parents got married—support, no matter what.

But the delivery person in me was on the clock. The company policy was strict: I needed a signature for this package, and I couldn’t leave it unattended. My phone buzzed with a reminder—confirm delivery within five minutes or risk a write-up. I glanced at Max, torn. He needed me, but so did my job. My heart pounded as I stood there, package in hand, caught between comforting my stepbrother and fulfilling my duty as a delivery person.
